cookies.title: Cookies - sweet or clingy?
cookies.paragraph1:
Your barista remembers your latte and your name. Sweet!
First-party cookies do that - login, preferences, did you see A or B, and that shopping cart you abandoned.
cookies.paragraph2:
Guy in a van? Different vibe.
Third-party cookies follow you everywhere, log everything, report to advertisers. That abandoned cart haunting every page? That's them.
cookies.firstParty: First-party cookies: set by the site you're on — logins, carts, "remember me," that sort of useful stuff.
cookies.sessionPersistent: Session vs. persistent: session cookies vanish when you close the tab; persistent cookies stick around for days or months, like glitter after a craft accident.
cookies.retargTitle: Retargeting in 4 steps (aka "why am I seeing those exact shoes?")
cookies.retargStep1: You check out Product X on Site A. A tiny "ad pixel" from AdCo loads.
cookies.retargStep2: AdCo drops a third‑party cookie: "User looked at Product X."
cookies.retargStep3: Later on Site B (also running AdCo), your browser presents that cookie to AdCo.
cookies.retargStep4: AdCo recognizes you and serves an ad for Product X everywhere, forever. Or at least until the cookie expires.
cookies.note: Note: Many browsers now block third-party cookies by default. Retargeting still happens via newer tricks (first-party tracking, server-side stitching, hashed emails). The game evolves.

tricks.title: Persuasion tricks in plain sight
tricks.body: Your interface isn't neutral. Inline prompts, progress meters, social proof — every microcopy push keeps you moving forward.
tricks.body2: Spot scarcity timers, risk-free guarantees, checkout microcopy, unstoppable autoplay. Once you see them, you can't unsee them.

hooked.title: Holy grail of Silicon Valley
hooked.body: Tech isn't neutral. It's engineered to trigger craving loops with every notification, feed refresh, and streak counter.
hooked.body2: Once you name the trigger-action-reward cycles, you can break them on purpose — and build healthier ones instead.

aboutGadgetTaming.title: <u>gadgetTamer</u> - 7 Pillars
aboutGadgetTaming.body:
1. Understand the design (goals and principles)
  2. Measure, notice, decide on your usage
  3. Remove triggers
  4. Design your digital environment: add friction to the undesirable
  5. Eliminate slip-ups: adjust access
  6. Curate info diet: who, when and how is able to reach you?
  7. What's the replacement: remove friction from your goals

recap.title: Which tricks have gotten you?
recap.patterns: Websites reuse proven persuasion patterns because they consistently guide visitors toward action.
recap.data: Your browser leaks a data trail—browser, device, referrer, even rough location—before you click anything.
recap.popups: Pop-ups are timed nudges; annoying, yes, but effective when matched to behavior.
recap.trust: Trust is earned with proof: testimonials, track record, and transparent storytelling.
